review.title: Towards Learning and Verifying Invariants of Cyber-Physical Systems by Code Mutation
review.abstract: Cyber-physical systems (CPS), which integrate algorithmic control with physical processes, often consist of physically distributed components communicating over a network. A malfunctioning or compromised component in such a CPS can lead to costly consequences, especially in the context of public infrastructure. In this short paper, we argue for the importance of constructing invariants (or models) of the physical behaviour exhibited by CPS, motivated by their applications to the control, monitoring, and attestation of components. To achieve this despite the inherent complexity of CPS, we propose a new technique for learning invariants that combines machine learning with ideas from mutation testing. We present a preliminary study on a water treatment system that suggests the efficacy of this approach, propose strategies for establishing confidence in the correctness of invariants, then summarise some research questions and the steps we are taking to investigate them.

sections.heading: 4 Correctness of Invariants
sections.text: In fact, it is a requirement that we wanted to avoid in the first place. As alternatives to the manual procedures that we propose, we propose two opposing approaches: to establish confidence in the correctness of invariants and to emphasize their suitability for CPS. Firstly, we will apply statistical model checks (SMC), a standard method for analyzing and verifying invariants, and secondly, we will not recognize their suitability for CPS.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Next Steps
sections.text: In this short paper, a novel approach to learning CPS invariants was proposed, which trains an ML technique such as SVM for positive and negative traces of sensor data, the latter achieved by applying mutation operators to copies of programs in the cyber part - the part of the CPS that we can most easily control. We presented a preliminary study on SWaT, a raw water treatment plant that suggests the effectiveness of invariant design in this way. Furthermore, we outlined the use of SMC and symbolic execution to build confidence in the accuracy of the learned invariants, and discussed their use in CPS applications such as physical test stations. Much work remains to determine the effectiveness of our approach to CPS. First, we will automate - as far as possible - our experiment on the SWaT simulator to allow classifiers to perform on multiple additional mutants and initial states of CPS that do not exhibit such behavioral differences.
